review_title: Experience Madison For Yourself, and You'll Never Leave.
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow, Biochemistry in Madison, WI
pros: Madison itself is a great place to live, work and play. It retains the atmosphere and charm of a small town, but provides many of the cultural benefits of a large city. U. Wisconsin Madison has many departments that work with one another, and are quite collegial toward one another. Many new construction projects have recently been completed or are being undertaken, and the facilities are top-notch for laboratory based science. In addition to it being a good work environment, it also provides an excellent outdoor beer garden, known as The Terrace at the Memorial Union, where you can converse about life, work, etc while watching the sun set over Lake Mendota.
cons:
The top administrative officials are so far removed from the workings of daily life that they miss opportunities to serve more effectively. This is likely the case in other large R01 schools, too.
Parking is problematic near campus, unless you pay the high fees to park 10-15 minutes away from your building.
. . .. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

review_title: My own experience has been both rewarding and challenging; I see positives and negatives in where we've been and change.
job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: We are in the process of a complete HR overhaul; to me, this is a good time to speak up and voice what we want.  Overall, the people here are very friendly.  I like coming to work, I enjoy the people I work with, and I love what I do.  We are definitely making the right steps to progress forward and make this a better place, and a more rewarding place, to work.
cons: There is still a caste system, and I feel that even with change, that won't go away.  There are middle-to-upper management problems with feedback and communication that is sometimes hard to work around, and campus doesn't do much to help or change that.  It's definitely a way of thinking, but I think as "newer" generations of work come in, and the information age gets younger, the old ways of thinking how things should be done will start to filter out.

pros: Work and life balance is good
cons: Institutional changes move very slowly

pros: they have good benefit packages
cons: they have really poor parking

review_title: The UWSC is a good student job, but crappy and soul crushingly awful at times.
pros: Most of all, the UWSC is highly flexible in terms of the amount of freedom you have in setting your own schedule.  They understand that people have lives outside of work, and that most of their workforce is comprised of students that have a number of obligations to fulfill other than their work schedule, and for the most part, they are very good at allowing you to rearrange your schedule so as to be the most convenient for you in terms of keeping all of your various obligations balanced.  I think that that is very nice of them to do.
cons: Sometimes the job gets to be mind numbing and absolutely terrible to do.  You are preying on every single call that no one ever answers the phone, because you simply cannot bear the thought of having to take another brain dead republican wisconsinite through the laborious process of qualifying them for one of the many, many pointless surveys offered by the UWSC.  And at the end of the day, you kind of feel like you are really intruding on other peoples lives, so it makes you feel a little bit defeated when you leave the office every night.  It sucks.

review_title: Taking care of the Academic but not the 'little' guy doing all the work.
job_title: Financial Specialist III in Madison, WI
pros: Research facility, world-known, great co-workers.
cons: Demanding a bachelor's degree even when experience tops what you learn in school.  Requiring that degree to even be accepted to interview; not matter what degree it is.  Lack of appreciation for the every day worker.  The expense of worthless items spent by the Department heads and the Academic staff.  People who don't know how to conduct business in business departments and situations.

review_title: Best college job available on campus
pros: Flexibility with hours was amazing.  They were always really good about days off and giving time for exams and such.  The management was good, and they let you know when you did a great job.  The job had a lot of autonomy, which was nice being able to make your own decisions, because in the "real world", there wont be someone sitting behind you telling you exactly what to do all the time.
cons: The raises were not given out on a fair basis.  The wages were pretty good, but I don't feel like I was getting paid the amount that I am worth as a dedicated employee.  I worked there for 3 years and only got one raise.

review_title: A great place to be -- if you can handle the bureaucracy.
pros: If you are passionate about learning and the opportunities a college education can give to a student, then UW is a great place to be. We are a service organization that help faculty, staff and students create and disseminate knowledge....Very family friendly place to work. Great benefits, including generous vacation.
cons: Very bureaucratic and political, being part of a state agency. Hierarchical culture.  Very hard to advance. To get a promotion, you have to leave and then come back at a higher level, or you have to wait around 20 years until the person a head of you retires.

review_title: A disgusting view into State employment and higher education administration
pros: The work/life balance cannot be beat.  All employers walk out the door at 4:30pm... no one iota of overtime is expected.
cons: You become petrified that State employment will render your brain unable to function in the outside world.  There is no concern for the bottom line, and decisions are made by leadership without any regard for cost-benefits analyses or other logical business motives.  There is no questioning leadership... the attitude is "well if that's what he wants, that's what we'll do."  So it is hard expending enormous effort for a project that you  know is only going to cost the taxpayers money and have no added benefit.  I thought that by going to work at a University, I would be surrounded by intelligent people.  Instead I feel the exact opposite.  Jobs are so secure there that most employees become very complacent.

pros: The University of Wisconsin is your standards research school.  There are reasonable support positions here (HR, Financials, etc), but nothing outstanding.  The school has made a big show out of establishing Individual Development Plans for students and post-docs, but this is largely a self-driven kind of thing, and the helpfulness of this initiative is largely dependent on how serious you and your PI take it (so, like everything in Grad School / Post Doc positions).
cons: The University of Wisconsin in in the unfortunate position of residing in the state controlled by Gov. Scott Walker.  This has a number of unenviable consequences.  First, the budget for the university has been slashed, and this will likely continue into the future.  Also, Walker legislates from his morality, so certain stem cell techniques are actually illegal now (have been since October 2015), and I personally know three researchers who have had to abandon certain experiments due to this.

pros: Very good benefits package compared to most private sector jobs today.  Generous time off.  Great position if you love to teach nutrition to multi-generational individuals.  You help educate limited income children, adults and older adults about nutrition and provide cost effective ways they can eat healthier.  This could be a good position for a couple who just needs extra income.  You will have a difficult time sustaining a family on this income alone.
cons: The wage is low for what is required of you.  Due to Gov. Walker's recent state employee changes, you automatically have 7% taken out of your pay to go towards your state pension.  You cannot refuse the 7% reduction.  So, the pension coupled with family health benefits taken out leaves you with very little money to live each month.  Unfortunately, I had to take a higher paying position else where for my family to financially survive.

review_title: Good place to be a grad student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Good support system for personal, professional, academic growth. Large graduate student community, good support staff. Some professors manage groups better than others, and there appears to be support for them to gain skills to do this. OK financial support for research and graduate students. Good medical/dental benefits for grad students. People know how to blow off steam and have a good time. Work hard/play hard
cons: Few professors are effective lab managers, compensation is low, not a variety of benefits for grad students, takes advantage of foreign students' inability to be funded by most federal research training grants, not a lot of support for developing skills for careers outside of academia

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: The graduate research programs are nationally ranked, your stipend will go a long way in Wisconsin, healthcare coverage is great, labs are well funded, and Madison is beautiful in the spring/summer months. The Wisconsin Idea is awesome and allows students to participate in lots of outreach opportunities. There is a lot of support to graduate students who wish to go down a non-traditional career path.
cons: The recent budget cuts to the UW-Madison and changes to tenure policy has and will continue to be a barrier to attracting/retaining top-level researchers. The winters in Madison are pretty awful if you aren't used to Midwest winters.

review_title: One of the best places to work in Madison
job_title: Senior Information Processing Consultant in Madison, WI
pros: The benefits are fantastic. The pay is comparable with private industry for mid-level people. They give bus passes to people each year. They have a very liberal retirement that they pay into as well as the ability for the employee to add. They have many services offered at no cost to the employee for counseling and health/fitness. Once a person passes a 6 month probation they are pretty much guaranteed never to be fired, which can be a drawback working with someone who no longer wants to work. It is generally a pretty campus to work and walk about in.
cons: There is no upward path for advancement. A person must apply for each new job in the University instead of being able to be promoted.

review_title: Overall a good place to work
pros: Intelligent workforce, which is an advantage in a university setting. Enough people who really care about doing a great job to motivate you. Shared governance ensures that you have opportunities to voice you opinions/concerns to the upper management. Job security if you are on hard money.
cons: Much lower than average pay as compared to other schools in the Big 10. Typical red tape and hassle due to working for the state. Enough people who have given up on plowing through the red tape to sometimes greatly fustrate you. Lack of job security if you are on soft money. University doesn't invest in training people to be good managers.

review_title: Andersen Library Circulation Desk at UW-Whitewater
job_title: Circulation Student Assistant in Whitewater, WI
pros: The work is fairly easy, and the staff is typically very friendly. It's not bad at all for a part-time student job. Scheduling is fairly flexible and classes take priority over work. For every 4 hours worked, there's a built-in 15 minute break, which is nice.
cons: The work can get very repetitive.  Late night shifts are also rather tiring, especially around finals week when it is difficult to get patrons to behave themselves and leave at closing time.  The pay starts at minimum wage and "merit raises" are only 10-15 cents per hour.

review_title: Grad school:  not exactly the military
pros: The competence of scientists and instructors is top notch.  Support staff are diligent, efficient and highly competent.  The pay is fantastic.  Facilities are robust with large resources for research in many fields.  As a theoretical physics based research department the folks at Chamberlin are unrivaled.  Finally, I present a unique skill-set that developed during my time as a Soldier in the US Army.
cons: The office setup is poor.  Multiple people per desk, offices are poorly kept and food, drinks, trash are abundant.  It appears that some of the foreign students actually live in the office complexes.  The coursework is beyond demanding and the qualifying requirement makes progress extremely stressful.

review_title: Dynamic place to work, opportunities for those who aggressively seek out new initiatives
pros: Terrific professionals in research and teaching. Best students are as capable as you will find at the most selective universities, making credit and non-credit teaching opportunities particularly rewarding. Benefits are competitive.
cons: Facilities and technology can lag behind other universities, especially private schools. Decentralized governance with a standalone alumni association, technology transfer office and foundation decrease efficiencies for the administrators. Inefficiencies compounded by regulatory requirements applied indiscriminately to all State of Wisconsin agencies.

pros: The University is a great environment for both work and play.  Madison is a great city, and there are so many opportunities within the University system!  The environment is very intellectually stimulating and challenging, which makes every day interesting and exciting!  In addition, there are great benefits associated with being a member of the university community!
cons: Depending on your career path, the opportunities may be limited.  The competition for open positions is extremely stiff, so if you are looking to advance quickly, it may not be the ideal workplace.

pros: The faculty and staff at UW Fox Valley are friendly and supportive.  Departments cooperate and support one another rather than compete.  Communication is transparent.  University leaders strive for a healthy work/life balance.  Recognition is fair and frequent.  Class size is small.
cons: The pay is below average.  There are periodic struggles with state legislature to ensure adequate funding.  Raises are negligible (1% for the 08/09 school year; 2% for the 09/10 year).   While opportunities to increase annual pay exist in the form of summer or interim appointments, opportunities are not evenly distributed across departments as summer and interim courses are based on demand.

job_title: Student Services Coordinator in Madison, WI
pros: It's a good job if you want to help students and serve students. It also can be pretty flexible.
cons: The people running the place might have lots of credentials after their names, but they are really incompetent when it comes to running an institution. Those around me were overpaid and underworked. People didn't do their jobs correctly but would still get promoted or threaten to leave by bringing in an outside job offer and they would get a raise and then stay. We would just hope they would actually leave...

pros:
-Gain team building experience
-Lead large numbers of student employees (600+)
-Variety of work - both office work as well as floor shifts
cons: The way that University Housing structures the employment hierarchy within the division of dining is not the most efficient. Many of the full time managers aren't helpful or knowledgeable, and the supervisors (students) are often left doing a majority of the work. My position easily could have been a full time job though my job description only said 18-30 (aprox.) hours per week.

pros:
UW-Parkside is a fine place to teach because regular faculty teach three classes each semester in most fields, and many classes are limited to 25 students.
Campus size
Beauty of campus
Excellent music, art and drama facilities.
Excellent Drama department.
cons:
UW-Parkside accepts more students who apply than any UW campus which means that there are more students who need pre-college courses in reading, writing, and math and more tutorial services.
I retired from teaching as an adjunct lecturer at UW-Parkside in approximately 2002 rather than the only option available as my last year there as 2009, my only option below.  I taught there full-time or part-time from 1972 to 1983 and periodically in later years until approximately 2002.

review_title: Wonderful place to work. The people are very friendly and are positive at all times.
pros: Working in a positive environment is what makes this job the spectacular. I come to work with the motivation and desire to work everyday. The work is at your own pace which again requires motivation on your part.
cons: Finding parking is the biggest challenge in this job. Since it's located downtown, expect to pay around $10 for an 8 hour shift to park in the parking ramp. Besides that, there aren't many cons about this job.

review_title: New leadership means this is a time of transition and promise.
pros: Colleagues are thoughtful and talented. Benefits make up for low salaries. Visionary leadership and a culture of serving students makes for meaningful work.
cons: Low pay compared to private sector. It is a time of transition in leadership so it's important to be nimble and willing to adapt to a changing vision. Economic challenges impact individuals through furlough days and taking on additional work as open positions go unfilled, not unlike every other workplace.

pros: I think that this school has high reputations, especially in engineering field. People can gain a lot of knowledge from this school. For example, there are several famous professors in electrical and computer engineering department.
cons:
This place has a really long winter about 6 months. The temperature is usually below -20 degrees 
during winter season. People usually choose stay in the building or house for working or entertainment. I felt boring during that time.

review_title: Felt great to help students be successful
pros: The school was a very comfortable environment. Everyone worked together tonfind new ways to help students. Also help me get involved in more on campus activities and groups. Great experience.
cons: The biggest challenge was students that didnt want to put the effort in and expected me to do it for them. Another common problem is those who would wait until the last minite to review for a test and expect to understand everything in a short period of time.

review_title: Do Not Work at this University
pros:
-Small
-Work directly with students as a Faculty
-Great medical
-Great Student Life
-Some supportive employees who are not faculty
cons:
A place that tolerates bullying and harassment; stressful, dysfunctional place to work.  Administration does not support a climate of acceptance and tolerance.  In fact, management failed to provide a safe work environment for their faculty.  Lies and allegations were tolerated by administration that promoted a hostile work environment.  

Criticisms and allegations lacked substantive, quantifiable evidence.  Repudiatory and disparate treatment by tenured faculty towards non-tenured faculty.


Poor pay and forced to take furlough days without pay.  Often overworked.

review_title: Morale is affected with a new governor who doesn't value education
pros: Working at a university is personally satisfying as I am affecting students' futures. The job never gets boring as there are always new students.
cons: Being in a public university system, it takes awhile to get things done due to the bureaucracy.  And with a new governor in office who doesn't seem to value education--he himself does not have a college degree--our future is uncertain.  The governor is determined to take away our right to bargain, and many of the benefits we negotiated in lieu of salary increases are now being threatened.

job_title: Part Time Undergraduate Research in Madison, WI
pros: The position helps to create close relationships with professors, give the employee a deeper understanding of complex topics, and can help to create a passion for a particular discipline and/or make professional goals more clear for the employee.
cons: Given that the work usually takes place during the academic term, it can sometimes distract from rigorous coursework. The compensation for the position isn't unfair, but also is not substantial and can impede a student from taking on more substantive part-time work.

review_title: Nice to work with a lot of smart people
pros: The staff is highly dedicated to the mission of a great public university. Benefits are good (e.g. vacation, health insurance, etc) and the ability to be creative is unsurpassed.
cons: Pay hasn't kept up due to reactionary management at the State level and political pressures from the Tea Party crowd.

pros: Beautiful state of the art building, supporting green initiatives and scientist collaborations. Daily tea and coffee served at 3pm to bring workers together. Has many symposiums and children's programs hosted here. Has its own cafe and restaurant inside.
cons: They decided to put only one set of bathrooms in the building to facilitate communication amongst scientists, while it is unlikely people would strike up as many conversations here.

review_title: Can be a satisfying place to build a career.
pros: Great students; Campus is finally upgrading facilities; La Crosse is beautiful place to live and very affordable with easy access to metro areas (Twin Cities and Madison are about two hours away).
cons: Still work to be done on upgrading some campus facilities; Salaries have been on the low end compared to other UW System campuses

review_title: It was a job, not a career.
job_title: Office Operations Associate in Madison, WI
pros: It's a state government job so all the perks and benefits are fantastic. While the salary might not be the greatest, not many organizations can compete with the benefits.
cons: I had a non-exempt job so it was just a daily grind to come in and out of work. The nice thing was that I had an excellent supervisor so it made everything easy.

pros: It's a great University that doesn't rest on its laurels. There is exciting stem-cell and alternative energy research on campus.
cons:
The salaries for graphic designers are low. No same-sex partner benefits although the new chancellor seems interested in changing that. In most departments, there are too many managers and not enough transparency. Projects can move very slowly. That said, every department is different because there is a lot of autonomy.

Their strength and monies seem to be invested in the sciences rather than the arts and humanities.

review_title: Prestigious, but unless you know someone, you will not work there nor continue to work there.
pros: If you actually manage to get into the company, it will open doors. You can advance, get onto other projects, start your own projects. It offers connections.
cons: You need to get it, but to do so you need to KNOW someone. If you don't know someone, you won't get hired. Their postings for jobs are shams; they already internally have a person in mind.

review_title: Great for undergraduates...until you graduate and work there.
pros:
You can't beat the energy of having 600 smart, motivated and interesting undergraduates from all over the world in your building each day. I was able to mentor some really great young adults that I'm still in contact with. It was very rewarding to see them grow and share my "real-world" experience with them. Exciting to be among some ground-breaking research that the faculty is doing. 
Gov. Walker took a bite out of the benefits and they weren't as great as they used to be, but they're still pretty good compared to private sector.
cons: Unfortunately, at UW-Madison is still basically run by "old white men" as it has been since when it was founded in 1900. It is a hostile place for a woman to work. Even though there are some female figureheads representing women at leadership levels on staff, these women see other smart women as competition and act accordingly. Female faculty are more independent from this behavior (although there have been equal-pay lawsuits recently). Bullying runs rampant, especially if you're "too sensitive" (ie human) and the alarming rate of attrition since fall of 2011 (new dean appointed) is a guarantee that you will be tasked with your job + part of someone else's that just left.

review_title: I have learned a lot, and been given the freedom to pursue my interests within the goals of the research group.
pros: There are some great opportunities for top-notch research.  The people I have worked with have all been very accommodating when family health issues have come up.
cons: It took me an exceptional amount of time to "prove myself" to my co-workers.  Working with such bright people who are quick to dismiss other ideas was a problem.

job_title: Survey Research Interviewer in Madison, WI
pros: The pay is good, especially if you're a student.  Raises are given twice a year based on performance.  Coworkers are interesting people, shifts leaders are usually friendly.  You're conducting academic studies so you're technically collecting data which is great to put on your resume. You gain telephone communication skills, heighten attention to detail,and  knowledge about survey research.  This kind of survey research isn't marketing or reviews, it's all academic.  Examples include, health surveys from the CDC or an asthma survey for a study conducted by UW-Madison.  It's really cool to be conducting survey's for such notable clients.  This company is one of the best survey centers in the US.
cons: You're basically a telemarketer but instead of selling stuff, you're trying to get people to take an academic survey.  You make tons of phones calls and most of the time, people are rude or hang up on you.  There's a lot of rejection (if you're not good with rejection, this job is definitely not for you).  The work is repetitive.  You make a bazillion calls a day.  There is one study everyone knows and you'll be calling that study for a few months until you learn how to conduct other studies.  That means you read the same questions over and over again (if someone picks up and agrees to do the survey with you).  Some surveys are 5-45 mins long; some even last an hour.  You have to remain objective, it's part of survey research.  If you're not a student, you're an LTE.  LTE's only get 20 hrs/week and get capped at a certain wage.  All shifts are 4 hours with a min of 12 hours a week.  You're required to work at least weekend shift.  Week day hours are 9-1, 1-5, or 5-9.  You can't have any other hours.  This makes scheduling extremely inconvenient.

pros:
The best reason to work as a research assistant is to get your schooling paid for and be able to live.  While this is considered an entitlement in many countries outside of the US, we're supposed to be so grateful for it.  

My work allows me to do the necessary research to get my PhD, and my adviser is an internationally known expert.
cons:
The UW doesn't pay nearly enough for research assistants compared to other schools, and unless you constantly haggle about salary, you will not get anything near the top of the range.  The bureaucracy is stifling at times.  

You will be lucky to get a 1/2 RA, for which you will most likely be expected to put in at least 40 hours/week.  You are essentially an indentured servant.  I often put in 60h/week or more, and am not allowed to go on vacations.  My adviser in general appears to be a nice guy, but is never around to supervise because he is always globe trotting.  The research scientists ultimately make the rules, and they want results to publish. 

I would advise finding another university that pays better and is in a better climate.  If you want the UW political climate, by all means come here, although I hear UC Berkeley pays better, and couldn't possibly work you as hard I've been worked here.  

People often say the benefits at the UW are 'awesome', but check out the benefits available elsewhere and you'll find that those at UW-Madison aren't anything special.

pros:
-academic atmosphere
-emphasis on work-life balance
-respectful management with a focus on equity and inclusion
-my managers do not micromanage or hover, but are always available when I need them
cons: -past issues with this specific department not being inclusive toward women - there has been a focus on remediating the problem since a few months before I was hired, and efforts/reorganization are ongoing at the time of this review

pros:
pretty flexible on hours
you get to work with students
work study possibility
very simple, easy work for slackers
management understands the student mentality and works to facilitate workers success
cons: it is totally mindless work. you are not expected to find things to do outside of the specific tasks you were assigned even if they are completed way ahead of schedule. just sit there and be bored

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Madison, WI
pros: Healthcare was excellent.  Free bus pass- very useful in Madison which has an excellent bus system.  Very good atmosphere for research and learning.  Top notch departments.
cons: No sick or personal days for post docs- leave will depend on your supervisor.  Parking is never free, even after hours.  Post docs fit into a weird category between students and staff, even though you are referred to as staff.  Professional development is for full staff members, with no opportunities for post docs.

pros: Decent benefits, acceptable pay if you stay around long enough, and
cons: People are exploited from the top down:  faculty are nurtured to be successful, and once they are the UW collects megabucks from their grants, grad students are cheap labor, postdocs can't get hired anywhere else, undergrads pay tuition and provide a cheap unskilled labor force, and nearly all staff are pressured to work a lot of unpaid overtime to meet arbitrary deadlines.  No room for advancement unless you are buddies with senior management.  Brown-nosing your immediate supervisor is required.

review_title: Great place for student and teaching assistants
pros: As a student, there is a fantastic social scene and a strong culture of balancing your studies with having a life.  Classes challenge you to learn.
cons: The environment is very liberal and can result in reluctance to vocalize conservative opinions or advocating conservative ideals

review_title: Certain institutions within UW-Madison totally worthwhile working for
job_title: Student Assistant for Online Course in Madison, WI
pros: Great staff.  Coworkers and management were all understanding and team-oriented.  It was a pleasure to work on projects together.  Management explained projects thoroughly and rewarded excellent performance with regular and helpful feedback.  Was able to learn a lot about web design while working there and able to increase responsibilities by being self-motivated as well as by accomplishing assigned tasks efficiently.  Very rewarding experience indeed.
cons: Um, none that I can think of.  Studying there on the other hand...

review_title: Well rounded experience with opportunities for leadership training.
pros: The city of Madison is fabulous, great community to be a part of. As an employee you get many of the same community benefits that the students receive.
cons: The people that work here don't leave so there can sometimes be a hard time trying to find advancement. The mindset of departments sometimes is not easily changed because the same leadership has been in place for many years.

review_title: Great place to work, however, uncertain future is troubling
pros: Work for a great cause. Higher Ed is a great job to show up for every day. Very rewarding career choice.
cons: WI is cutting higher ed budgets BIG time. Working at the U is tough because every faculty member is wondering how their dept. will look after the next round of cuts.

review_title: Can be awesome if you are an unclassified or academic employee
pros: Flexible schedule, excellent benefits( although slowly being taken away), excessive vacation and sick leave, easy access to experts in various fields.
cons: Pay is on the low end for Big 10 institutions. Employees have to pay ~$800+/year  for parking on campus. Cost of living in the area is high compared to the compensation.  There is minimal room for advancement, as expected. High-level jobs go to high degrees only.

review_title: Great school for PhD in biosciences
pros: There are several large biosciences programs on campus and a lot of peer to peer contact, the professors are all knowledgeable and for the most part very open to sharing.
cons: The school is very large, so you have to make your own opportunities. If you want experience outside of your department, you need to take the initiative to make it happen on your own.

review_title: Decent place if you are looking for family balance
job_title: Senior IT Consultant in Madison, WI
pros: If you want a laid back work environment with a good life balance, this is the place to be. Also Madison is an excellent place to raise a family. You will have great ob security since most IT jobs are unionized and it is very rare for people to be layed off.
cons: Little career progression, since most people tend to stay on average 15 to 20 years :)

review_title: Education is fair, but more focus on collaboration with industry is needed.
pros: The benefits are good. Opportunities for research are present. Administrative staff is very helpful. Close to the lake and other city amenities.
cons: Teaching curriculum is narrow focused and does not include practical experiences. The faculty is not well trained with respect to teaching and use a model that is dated and ineffective.

pros: During my undergraduate years I worked as a research assistant in three different research laboratories focusing primarily on environmental and engineering research.  The biggest pro is that the enormous variety of research conducted at the University presents the opportunity to try different fields and find your passion.  I admired all my supervisors and enjoyed working as part of talented research teams that were passionate about their work and conducted impactful studies used by governments in policy design.
cons: I have no cons to mention.

review_title: Stellar Institution; Take Pride In Your Job!
job_title: Program Assistant in River Falls, WI
pros: UWRF is a quality institution with a great plan for moving forward.  The employees at UWRF really take pride in their work and pride in the university as a whole.
cons: Most jobs are on a year-by-year contract so you are unsure if you are being renewed for the next year.  Wisconsin has a budget shortfall this year as well so a lot of people are nervous they are going to lose their job.

pros: Works around your schedule and really great place to work, most of the coworkers are great and the management understands that you are a student first
cons: Gets a bit dull at times, not always enough to do.  Some coworkers are not exactly the most friendly people.

review_title: Relaxed university setting, but pay is low and benefits are slowing being taken away
job_title: Senior Web Developer in Madison, WI
pros: Very relaxed work place.  Great, intelligent coworkers. General stability.  You're not making money for other people, which is a huge plus.
cons: No Raises, lower than average pay - compared against other universities and the private sector in general. Only three ways to get a raise - promotion, transfer, or counter-offer.

review_title: Excellent Work Environment for UW-Madison Students
pros: The staff are willing to help you with anything and are very supportive. Allow a good mix between on-the-job fun and also work. Great pay.
cons: Minimal room for advancement, but given the nature of the work, that is to be expected. That is the only con.

review_title: It was a great learning experience
pros: The best reason to working at the University of Wisconsin was that I could study while working at the University.
cons: One of the biggest drawbacks of working at the University of Wisconsin is that the pay is not sufficient enough for the amount of work being done.

review_title: Housing makes sure to cater to the residents, but knows it needs to make money while doing it.
pros: people environment location conditions supervisors coworkers university student campus Madison fun privilege involvement academics community diversity time places resources programming
cons: I feel that University of Wisconsin Housing could work on aspects of diversity because it is a significant portion of the community.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: The University of Wisconsin has a strong reputation as a good research university so completing research there is a very strong accomplishment.
cons: The professors here are paid low wages compared to their colleagues at other institutions, as an undergrad, the wages are low compared to other jobs an undergrad could get.

review_title: Good but could have been better in some regards.
job_title: Sports Conditioning Inter in Madison, WI
pros: Amazing facility, top notch equipment, large training space, multiple gym locations, trained, competent staff, top not programs for athletes and students alike. Strong campus vibe and college indentity.
cons: Internships in the athletics department are like a feeder machine, you go in, do your thing, and head out. Not much chance of staying around.

review_title: Boring monotonous work, poor pay, great co-workers
pros: They were willing to work around my other commitments in life. In addition, I could not have asked for better co-workers.
cons: The work was often remedial and boring. We were often left to figure tasks out on our own and were expected to have a knowledge base I lacked going in.

pros: If you are a college student looking for employment, this is a great place to start.  They work around your academic schedule, and is convenient to work on campus.  The experience you gain can be  used to gain future employment
cons: The pay is not all that great as you are working for the state.  Recently the management structure was reconfigured, which took almost 2 years to adjust to.

review_title: Flexibility + Health Insurance + Degree = Worth it.
pros: Working towards a degree and being compensated in doing so.  The health insurance is great.  In addition being a graduate student permits one to be flexible in the hours worked.
cons: The expectations can be very high and sometimes it requires sacrificing significant personal time.  The low pay is also disappointing.

pros:
great benefits - can't beat state benefits to compensate for low salaries
great co-workers - people who got your back when you need them
great atmosphere - enjoy working with students is a must!
cons:
salary - long process to get a raise, not a private-sector type of work environment
hiring process - may take up to 6 months before you hear anything
depending on job function, can work up to 45-50 hours

review_title: I have been a student driver for 4 years.
pros:
You are done with work before class typically, you can schedule you're work day around classes.
Almost no work on weekends.
Base pay is max student pay.
Great job to have during school.
cons:
You have to be there at 6am every weekday.
You can not get a promotion.
One Saturday per month you will have to be there from 6-9am.

review_title: Somewhat unfulfilling and monotonous, but learned critical thinking and useful skills with technology.
pros: Opportunity to learn from top IT professionals. Very flexible to customize your schedule to work around your personal life or academic life for students.
cons: No direct feedback was ever given. Instead of feedback, senior employee would talk amongst themselves and deliver feedback in a passive-agressive manner.

pros: Great benefits (healthcare, retirement matching, and vacation) but slightly eroded over the past decade.
cons: Pay for certain positions does not keep up with increases in cost of living.  Processing a raise in the bureaucracy can be like pulling teeth sometimes.

pros: Most jobs are pretty independent. You don't interact with your supervisor very often. This can be good or bad depending on your style.
cons: Unorganized management. Extremely bureaucratic. It takes forever to get a little thing done because 6 different people must be consulted, and none of them want to accept responsibility.

review_title: A great place to work and grow.
pros: Benefit package is good, leadership is very competent and open, good communication across lines, fair, and caring environment.
cons: Salary is lower than peers in private industry, however the benefit package compensates for a great portion of the difference.  Vacancies in higher level positions are filled by searches and not be promotion from within.

review_title: Great employer in a fantastic city
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Madison, WI
pros:
Madison is a wonderful city. Easy going and open society.
Student sport facilities that are open to staff.
cons:
Unwilling emigrant visa assistent at University level. I needed a lawyer to tell her my situation does indeed qualify for obtaining a green card.
Quite a bit of paperwork for reimbursements of invited speakers. Privacy sensitive info had to be shared.

pros: University Housing offers a wonderful work environment for students, with competitive pay, flexible scheduling, excellent training and great opportunities for experience in management.
cons: You are forced to work during two holidays each year, and also during many football games. Some desks require 24 hour staffing, so some overnight shifts are also required.

review_title: A great place for bioengineering, new equipment, great resources and great opportunities for interdisciplinary research
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Madison, WI
pros:
- high impact research, top scientists are present in faculty
- friendly and uncomplicated collegues
- great potential and easy access of collaboration
- new equipment and great resources
- Madison is agreat place to live and to get connected
cons:
- long winters in the Mid west
- it may take a while until it is known as Harvard, Berkeley or MIT

job_title: IS Technical Services Consultant in Madison, WI
pros: Very flexible work hours in a self-driven environment. To succeed at UW you need to be a self driven person who knows their stuff. There are a lot of opportunities to do ground up application implementation which can be a lot of fun.
cons: There are too many projects for the number of technical staff. While many projects are interesting the constant context switching can get to be a drag.

review_title: Things are going down the tubes, and it's not entirely the University's fault.
pros: It's a great institution with awesome faculty and staff, wonderful students, a gorgeous campus, and a wide variety of disciplines within the various colleges. The reputation is there for a reason.
cons: Scott Walker, Scott Walker, and the industry-wide shift away from the tenure model. My particular department is now down two T-T lines, after retirees were never replaced. It's disheartening to say the least.

pros: Excellent group of people with a good work-life balance.  Opportunities for learning and movement across different jobs.
cons: Lots of red tape and changing policy is difficult.  Needs to be split off from the government and stand alone so that the decisions being made are in the best interest of the schools and the students attending and not the government politicians.

review_title: UW-Madison is a good research institute.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Madison, WI
pros: UW-Madison is a well respected research institution, especially in the biological sciences.  It has attracted and retained a large number of skilled PIs who provide research opportunities in a wide variety of subfields.  The university is also home to an excellent set of facilities.
cons: The faculty vary quite a bit in their commitment to mentorship, and their accessibility.

review_title: A good place to work considering it's a large "system"
pros: Meet interesting people; great variety of work and research going on; super vacation time and good benefits package
cons: Takes longer to accomplish simple tasks (purchasing good, basic contracts, etc.) due to the State of Wisconsin System the University must follow. Goes with the territory.

review_title: It's my first job and I got what I deserved
pros: Good place to live. And I learned a lot of stuffs here in my own area, which helps me a lot.
cons: There is a lack of flexibility. Sometimes I wanted to learn something else to stretch myself, but there is not enough such opportunities.

pros: UW-Madison is pretty average university, and if you are research associate in competitive field this means dead-end job. it generally has this wondrerfull mid-western vibe 'let's pick some very ambitious goal and despite we have no idea how to get there we will try very, very hard, and probably smth. will happen'
cons: WI is pretty depressing place to live, salary though is competitive

review_title: Teaching is not a priority, so I was a teeny blip on the radar.
job_title: Assistant Faculty Associate in Madison, WI
pros: Great healthcare benefits, great location.  Lots of resources for furthering your education, in the form of free seminars, many people to go to for advice (especially staff).
cons: Politics.  A structure of hierarchical medieval-like royalty, with the tenured professors at the top.  If you want parking, be prepared to shell out at least a grand a year.

pros:
- Fun, easy going place to work.
- Great salary compared to similar jobs at other institutions
- Given lots of freedom
cons:
- Not very challenging
- Employees as a whole are not motivated
- Unclear organizational chart
- Disorganized collaboration between departments

review_title: Great Learning Experience, Established Career Skills In a great environment
pros: Great people in the office, who were helpful with onboarding process. Always was a comfortable place to be in the office.
cons: It is hard to think of any downsides to working at the UW. One difficult part is that they receive and incredibly high amount of applications for each position, so it can be hard to stand out from the pool at first.

review_title: Great people working to help students gain employment
pros: Friendly environment, direct interaction with students and employers, technologically adept and always looking to stay up-to-date, perfect location, unlimited resources for finding a career.
cons: Not a very high-paying job, unless you want to be a career advisor, there's not a lot of room for growth, if you're a student working there you need to be prepared to help older employees with anything and everything technological

review_title: The norm for life as a Grad Student/Researcher
pros:
Same great heath insurance plan as the faculty and staff
Good pay on grad student salary scale
Fun and affordable town
cons: Once you receive your degree there aren't a ton of other job oppurtunities within the area if you want to stay local.

review_title: A great experience for the position I had
pros: Working as a program assistant was a great experience for me.  I was able to learn a lot of valuable skills for the office and work place that will truly help me in the long run when I begin searching for full-time work.
cons: The compensation was lacking a little, and I was never able to work full-time or gain more responsibility in my position.

review_title: A good job with decent pay.
pros:
Awesome student supervisors
Normally good co-workers
Flexible hours
Good pay for a University job
cons:
Upper management does not care about student workers
Management constantly making changes to procedures
Embarrassingly incompetent co-workers can slip through the cracks and be a detriment to everyone

pros:
Good health benefits, although difficult to understand and complicated 
Give good time off, including weekends and holidays
Decent amount of job responsibility
cons: They work you really hard, you have to put in a lot of time for little reward. It is difficult/nearly impossible to get promoted.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Excellent access to top notch researchers and resources. The facilities are state of the art. Campus is accessible and beautiful. Staff and managers are flexible, encouraging, and supportive.
cons: It is a bureaucratic organization so many of the administrative processes are slow and cumbersome. The university was recently hit with state policies that increased out of pocket health care costs for most employess.

pros: This position paid for my grad school tuition and provided my a stipend. It basically made it possible for me to get my master's degree in CS. My advisor was available when needed and we were able to work well together to achieve my goals.
cons: You experience as a research assistant here will depend on you department and advisor.

pros: The city has a very good atmosphere, and the research evironment and contacts obtained are pretty good. In addition, people are all friendly.
cons: On one hand, the salary is less compared to the industry. On the other hand, the career track is less satisfactory compared to the industry.

pros: Generally, the research funding is good, and most device you need is available. You can arrange your own time.
cons: The salary is low, and the research pressure is intense. The field is very competitive, and you have to be quick. So many people works day and night.

pros: Great opportunities for growth. Great benefits. Good Salary. Vibrant work location. Great city in which to live. Close to other large cities.
cons: Winter weather can be a bit hard on some individuals. Certain areas are understaffed due to budget shortfalls. Salary is only competitive.

review_title: Good overall experience, soured by stagnation at the end.
pros: A state with a strong union presence and a still-respectable civil service ethic; lower cost-of-living then the coasts; excellent public education system (and generally a nice place to raise kids); academic environment; friendly people in the area.
cons: Broad disconnect between central and campus IT operations; lackadaisical upper management; difficulty in progressing internally (inadequate career path at the upper levels); terrible climate.

review_title: UWM was a great place to work & learn
pros: health insurance, payscale, flexibility, friendly environment, extent of authority
cons: Overall it was good. There should observe carefully that which instructor was able to increase the students' grades.

pros: Benefits are wonderful and the workplace is professional-casual. Schedules are flexible as well.
cons: At time it feels the organization isn't operating as a whole; rather, different people are operating their own projects.

review_title: My experience as a scientist here has been very positive
pros: Flexibility of schedule and excellent benefits.  The working environment is filled with youth and it can be contagious
cons: In the school of engineering, there is still the "old boys network" mentality here.  Also, no raises or cost of living increase and more budget cuts to come soon.

review_title: Like a university, only with worse benefits, more administrative meddling, and higher costs
pros: We have a nice building and friendly staff. We get a better salary than the university. And we get to be on a university campus.
cons: It's like UW Madison except with more money-driven micro-meddling by the organization's leadership, extra trustee gladhanding, higher overhead costs, and less job security.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros:
It is a big university with a lot of opportunities
Campus is nice and research facilities are well funded and up-to-date
There is obviously a good amount of money currently in the UW system
cons:
Stipends are some of the lowest out there
Madison is quickly becoming very expensive for a midwest city
The future of the university is a little murky with Scott Walker at the helm of the state

review_title: University of Wisconsin Press (UW Press) Lacks Any Leadership
pros: UW Press is a great place to work if you like having constant (shady) layoffs , moody management, favoritism, and sleepless nights.
cons:
UW Press leadership continues to use precious resources to travel around the globe. They have no idea how to run an organization or how to treat people working for them with respect.  Their plan is to push out the knowledgeable staff and emergency hire their ill quipped student replacements, people that will not question his judgement. 

UW Press continues to lose money year over year because of the decisions that the leadership makes.  Empathy or compassion isn't in their vocabulary.  Being a servant leader isn't in their pedigree.  Temper tantrums and disrespect are the norm during business meetings.

UW Press is also known for shady layoffs including forcing people into retirement early only to replace them with students.  On one occasion, they laid off someone while on maternity leave.  This is the type of organization you would be dealing with by working here.  

Do more with less is definitely the culture.  Don't forget about having to pay $1,200/year to park going forward, especially when you will never receive a merit increase.

Just in case you missed it, there is no hope for advancement or merit increases.  Starting wages are poverty level and it doesn't get any better from there.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros:
-High-level research facilities
-Well-funded research and assistantships
-Great benefits for grad students and their significant others/spouses
-Fantastic location
-Other grad students are supportive and foster a great working and learning environment
cons:
The cons are essentially what would be expected in a grad school environment:
-High stress environment
-Stipend is low relative to the cost of living
-Work-life balance hard to maintain
-Faculty members often have unreasonable expectations/standards for grad students

review_title: Great research community with many opportunities for a scientist
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Very large university with a lot of research equipment available for shared use. There is a specialist in just about ever field to consult with and most people are very willing to collaborate or give advice.
cons: As with anywhere there are some professors who are not willing to collaborate - in general this is not the case

pros: Good city. Near neighborhood is good. Good place to retire.
cons: Two salary increase in last 6years, each is 1%，increasingly lower health and retirement benefit. No real IT support.they hire students to pretend IT people, they mess up all the time.

pros:
Here is a list of reasons to love U. Wisconsin
- Great city.
- Low overheads.
- Good students.
